Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon I briefly considered it out of curiosity. We have a Cleveland clinic in Toronto who does it but it just doesn't have enough historical data to make me feel comfortable with it. There is very little qualitative information on it. A lot of quantitative information but that to me is just fluff. I may be old fashioned but I like to take my lead from my urologist who is open and honest and lays out all the alternatives, makes his recommendation and then lets you decide. I would have no reason to second guess my doctor as he has spent years of time and tons of money getting an education. It may well be in 10 years they may have hard data that can show how proton beams is better overall than other options. Right now I just don't see it. B Don't believe your statement is correct since Cleveland Clinic Canada has no proton beam radiation therapy, in fact Canada has no proton beam clinics but two are being built now with one in Vancouver and another one in Toronto but they won't be done until late 2014. Canadian residents who require proton treatments are referred to Chicago's ProCure Proton Center for treatment with all medical expenses paid (patients pay the lodging) by Canada. I know because I met 4 Canadian residents with late stage cancer getting their treatments there.
Posts.Title: What I Wish I Knew Before my Proton Beam Treatments

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JustSlappy Here's what I know about proton beam: It is extremely expensive ($50,000-$150,000), though Medicaid does cover it. A lot of insurance companies don't. First, they'll surgically implant seeds in your prostate, which they will use to guide the proton beams. Then, you'll get radiated once a day for about 9 weeks. There are NO limits as to what you do during that 9-week period. And there's little if any discomfort during the therapy. The big advantages, to me, are that your chances of leakage are much lower than surgery, and your likelihood of ED is delayed (I've been told anywhere from 6 months to 5 years). The extent of ED is a big unknown for proton beam, which is too bad because it is, to me, a big reason to do it instead of surgery. Guys who have had it seem to swear by it. Unfortunately, there's hardly any good data available on the side effects. And there are none of the other standard surgery risks like, well, death or infection. And no catheter. The biggest disadvantages are that there's no follow-up pathology as there is with surgery, so your PSA test is the only way to know if you are cancer-free. There's also risk of rectal issues, since the tip of the rectum gets radiated in the process. A small percentage (5%, i think, or maybe even less) suffer serious rectal issues that require treatment while more folks suffer temporary stuff like constipation, etc. As with any radiation, there's the slight chance of secondary cancers, which usually develop 8-10 years later, if they develop at all. And, as with any radiation, it makes any prostate surgery difficult, if doable at all, later. Just curious if anyone here has direct experience. thanks Yes, I have direct experience with the proton beam therapy. Completed 44 sessions recently in Chicago. My PSA went from double digit before treatment to now 0.01. Main advantage of proton beam radiation vs Xray radiation is the way proton releases its energy in the tumor since it enters the body with extremely low energy to avoid any damage then when it reaches the target (tumor), it releases the full energy attacking the tumor. Once it is done, the energy essentially fizzles out whereas Xray enters the body thru good tissues into the tumor then comes out in the back again thru good tissues. Proton minimizes collateral damage to the rectum and bladder. Not only that each patient is inserted a balloon then filled with water to further protect the rectum plus the bladder must be full before proceeding to prevent damage to the bladder. If everything checks out, then they'll proceed with the proton beam which only lasts less than 2 minutes. For patient with imbedded prostate (prostate grown into the bladder or touching the bladder), a special pencil beam technique is used to precisely give proton beam to the prostate without any scatter. There are only 5 such pencil beam facilities in US, and one is in Chicago's Warrenville proton clinic. The other advantage of proton therapy is the virtual nonexistent side effects since a patient can continue to run, jog, swim, work, .... as if nothing had happened. Yes, cost is higher than robotic surgery, Xray radiation but most insurance covers this therapy. Only less than a handful of the insurers refuse coverage. Medicare covers it for sure. Proton beam treats all sort of tumors especially in kid where they are more sensitive than adults. It is effective in treating prostate, lung, breast, neck, sinus, throat, ocular (eye), head, brain, .... type of cancer. For those of you who are interested in finding out more of this proton beam treatment, the ProCure Proton Clinic in Warrenville, IL (next to Naperville) is having an Open House this Sat (11/2) from 9 to 2 where the public can tour the entire facilities including the star, the 3-story high cyclotron machine which generates the proton beam. Hope this helps.

Posts.Title: What I Wish I Knew Before my Proton Beam Treatments

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gearloose The main reason for having your bladder full during treatment is because when full the bladder rises higher in the pelvis exposing prostate more plus thus minimizing rad exposure to the bladder. Also when full the bladder pushes the small intestine out of the way also helping to minimize exposure. Gearloose is 100% correct in his explanation for having a full bladder during radiation. Furthermore many radiation clinics also require patients to have a balloon inserted in the rectum then filled with water so it is full and away from the prostate. The amount of water varies with each individual. Ranges from typically 24 oz to 32 oz. The exact amount is pre-measured and the amount of time it takes to fill your bladder is also measured. Most patients come in 50 mins before appt time then they have 10 mins to finish drinking their water. You wait 40 mins before you get in to change to get on the table. Once you are on the table, the therapist checks to make sure you are indeed full and also free of gas. If bladder is too full, you'll need to empty a bit. If not full enough, you need to drink a bit. If they detect gas, then it'll need to be sucked out before radiation can start. Typical patients on radiation are placed a strict diet to minimize gas. However, many smaller radiation clinics don't have such requirements.
Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About External Beam Radiation Treatments
